name: Dependency management for Mendix Studio Pro 9.0.3 Beta
body:
### Dependency Management
With this release Native Template supports the newly introduced Native Dependency management system released with Mendix Studio Pro 9.0.3 in conjunction with Mendix Native Mobile Builder.

Native widgets and JS actions can now define their Native Dependencies. Mendix Native Mobile Builder, collects the dependencies and sets up your Native Template with exactly the dependencies that are needed. 

### Mobile Toolkit
Mobile Toolkit is a new configuration CLI that we introduced to the Native Template. This way we are moving the responsibility of configuring your project to the Template, allowing off-line users a path to auto configuring their project that previously was impossible due to the online requirement of the Native Mobile Builder. The cli supports a single command: 

`native-mobile-toolkit configure --config-path='./config.json'` 

or 

`npm run configure`

Native Mobile Builder writes to the config.json and commits assets to relative locations. The CLI then reads the config and handles, configuring the projects and moving any assets to the right locations for the projects. 

### Fixes 
- Target SKD reverted to 29 to support legacy storage on Android API 30
- Reverted Android Gradle Plugin version to 4.0.2 to fix a short coming of App Center and version 4.1.x
- Updated the React Native Device Info library to fix security issues
- Patched React Native Image Picker to fix an issue with duplicate images on Android.

name: New Capabilities support
body:
### Disclaimer

This release is required to use the Capabilities support introduced with the new Mendix Native Mobile Builder. As long as you have not updated you won't be able to make use of that functionality in the tool.

### Capabilities support

With the release of Mendix Native Mobile Builder, included when installing Mendix Studio Pro 8.15 or later, we are introducing a new approach in linking dependencies. 

While previous versions  of Native Template would have all core dependencies linked by default; for example an app would have Firebase even though it is not using any functionality; with the new approach we are building on top of React Native's auto linking behaviour and extending it a step further.

We gathered all core functionalities and grouped them under the platform specific `capabilities.*.json`  files. With a simple boolean toggle Native Template is able to link the required dependencies for the enabled capability, even the non auto-linkable ones. This happens as part of the pod installation for iOS and building on Android. After each change to this files remember to run `pod install` and build your Android project, so that the new files can be generated.

Some steps, like the inclusion of the Google Service configuration, or the google map api, are still manual, if you are building locally.
If you would like to further simplify these steps consider using the Mendix Native Mobile Builder to just configure your project and build your project however you like.

name: Extending capabilities support
body:
### Breaking change
While playing with our new capabilities support we identified some shortcomings.
In the initial implementation we thought of both platforms as a single configuration. "Less is more" they say, but in this particular case, less was too limiting. Therefor this update brings the splitting of the `capabilities.json` file to two new files, `capabilities.android.json`, and `capabilities.ios.json`. This allows the toggling of capabilities as needed for each platform.

#### What does that mean for Native Mobile Builder users: 
If you are using the Native Mobile Builder. Make sure you are using 0.9.x or later and there's nothing to fear, the builder will take care of things when re-building your project.

#### What does that mean for advance tinkerers:
If you are building locally, keep in mind that for enabling the needed capabilities the respective files for each platform need to be modified.
In addition, **on iOS**,  you will need to run `pod install`, as code generation is a sub-step of the pod installation flow. 

### Push notification support for Native Mobile Builder
On top of that functionality, we introduced Push Notifications support with just a few clicks. 

Jump into the Capabilities page and enable Push Notifications. Setup your Google Service configuration files, build and the new app should have Push Notifications configured.

**Offline tinkerers**
Enable the push notification capability for the platform you want by editing the appropriate `capabilities.*.json`, add the Google Service configuration file for each platform as advised by the platform's documentation and you are good to go.

### Improvements
- Added support for XCode 12.
- Added missing iPad icons, that would lead to apps being rejected when committed to TestFlight.
- Enabled legacy storage support to allow for some failing file operations to work correctly on Android 10 and later.
- Fixed a bug in our generator logic, that would lead to local Android builds to fail when running on Windows.
